name: Future You
description: There are 47,000 possible variations of robot in Future You. There's probably not that many in all of screen culture, but these ones stand out.

constellations_other.name: A brief history of black holes on-screen
constellations_other.description: In 1916, Albert Einstein predicted black holes through his theory of general relativity. That mix of science and imagination can be seen in Marshmallow Laser Feast’s Distortions in Spacetime. These other works are fascinated by these cosmic giants and represent an evolution in computer graphics and VFX.

end.title: Hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy. - Volume 1.
end.creator_credit: Alan J.W. Bell and British Broadcasting Corporation
end.brief_description: This is the story of the Hitchhiker’s guide to the galaxy. Perhaps the most remarkable - certainly the most successful - book ever to come out of the great publishing corporations of Ursa Minor. The story of Arthur Dent, a seemingly normal Englishman whose ordinary life suddenly takes a startling turn one Thursday. A Thursday which becomes steadily more extraordinary when his buddy Ford Prefect imparts the terrible, hideous news: He’s not from Earth and the Earth’s going to be demolished in 12 minutes to make way for a new hyperspace bypass! This program brings to life once more the magic of the cult TV series.

constellations_other.name: Scripture for spiritual connections and sci-fi futures
constellations_other.description: Connections between people, animals and the environment in sci-fi stories, videogames, art and film.

constellations_other.description: There are 47,000 possible variations of robot in Future You. There's probably not that many in all of screen culture, but these ones stand out.

links.description: TARS and other robots personalities in Interstellar were inspired by Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy, which features robots with intelligence and emotion, like Marvin, the depressed android.

start.title: Hitchhiker's guide to the galaxy. - Volume 1.
start.creator_credit: Alan J.W. Bell and British Broadcasting Corporation
start.brief_description: This is the story of the Hitchhiker’s guide to the galaxy. Perhaps the most remarkable - certainly the most successful - book ever to come out of the great publishing corporations of Ursa Minor. The story of Arthur Dent, a seemingly normal Englishman whose ordinary life suddenly takes a startling turn one Thursday. A Thursday which becomes steadily more extraordinary when his buddy Ford Prefect imparts the terrible, hideous news: He’s not from Earth and the Earth’s going to be demolished in 12 minutes to make way for a new hyperspace bypass! This program brings to life once more the magic of the cult TV series.

end.title: Maison Autonome
end.material_description: Single-channel video, stereo sound. Duration: 30:00mins, looped
end.brief_description:
An array of delightful characters strut towards you, flaunting a wild range of forms, sizes and materials. Each model in this fantasy fashion parade has their own anthropomorphic walk and personality, as well as unique garments and costumes that could only exist in the digital sphere. In an age when we’re anxious about artificial intelligence, these dapper androids suggest that a friendlier relationship between machines and humanity is possible.

Maison Autonome is a continuation of Universal Everything’s fascination with choreography. When characters (or real people!) sashay down a catwalk, they don’t walk the way they normally do. It’s highly stylised, an expressive mode of motion and way of presenting yourself – like dance. You can hear the performance in the stylish soundtrack and see it in the swing of the robots’ hips and the poses they make before they strut away.

There are 150 models in this 30-minute computational couture show, which takes the language of fashion and makes it oversized, fluid and truly space-age. Can you spot the smallest robot? Which one is your favourite?

Creative Director: Matt Pyke
Executive Producer: Claire Spencer Cook
3D Generative Animation: Chris Perry
Sound Design: Simon Pyke
Studio Technician: Spike Thompson

constellations_other.name: Future You
constellations_other.description: There are 47,000 possible variations of robot in Future You. There's probably not that many in all of screen culture, but these ones stand out.

links.description: The robots who feature in Universal Everything’s Maison Autonome aren’t depressed. A few of them look a little like Marvin, with their futuristic outfits and mechanical joints, but they brim with catwalk like confidence and cheekiness.

That mix of science and imagination can be seen in Marshmallow Laser Feast’s Distortions in Spacetime. links.description: Some of the robot reflections that you can become in Universal Everything’s Future You bear a striking similarity to TARS, the robot in Christopher Nolan’s Interstellar.

end.title: Contact
end.creator_credit: Robert Zemeckis, Joanna Johnston, Arthur Schmidt, Steve Starkey, South Side Amusement Company, Warner Bros. Pictures, Ed Verreaux, James V. Hart, Michael Goldenberg, Ann Druyan and Carl Sagan
end.brief_description: A radio astronomer receives the first extraterrestrial radio signal ever picked up on Earth. As the world powers scramble to decipher the message and decide upon a course of action, she must make some difficult decisions between her beliefs, the truth, and reality.

constellations_other.name: Future You
constellations_other.description: There are 47,000 possible variations of robot in Future You. There's probably not that many in all of screen culture, but these ones stand out.

links.description: The space travel in Interstellar is based on the work of physicist Doctor Kip Thorne, which were also the basis for the method of space travel in Carl Sagan’s Contact, which was adapted into a film in 1997, which like Interstellar, starred Matthew McConaughey.

end.title: Distortions in Spacetime
end.credit_line:
Marshmallow Laser Feast

Commissioned by Manchester Science Festival, part of the Science Museum Group in partnership with The British Science Festival and University of Hull
end.brief_description: Marshmallow Laser Feast invites you to experience the formation of a black hole with their immersive artwork, Distortions in Spacetime.

links.description: Cosmos educated millions on astrophysics and the relationship between stars and life on earth, popularising the idea that ‘We’re made from star stuff’. This idea is key to Marshmallow Laser Feast’s Distortions in Spacetime.
